title: Everyday heroes honoured for bravery saving lives with first aid
text:
Winners at the Everyday Heroes awards last night (Picture: Johnny Green)

An incredible teen who saved his brother’s life when he was impaled on the handlebars of his bike was among those honoured by St John Ambulance last night.

The charity hosted an annual award ceremony to recognise the incredible contributions of many of their volunteers, faced with life-threatening situations.

Jack Smith, 14, was mountain biking with his brother Connor when he saw the younger boy fall from his bike.

He tried to stand up and immediately collapsed – so Jack took decisive action. He saw Connor was bleeding from his stomach so ripped off his own shirt and put pressure on the wound to stem the blood flow while calling 999.

In the time until the ambulance arrived, he kept reassuring his brother as well as applying pressure to stem the blood flow after he severed his femoral vein.

Connor is now on his way to a full recovery thanks to the actions of his big brother.

Young Hero winner Jack Smith (Right), with his brother Connor (Left) (Picture: Johnny Green)

Jack was awarded the Young Hero award during the ceremony at London’s Hilton Bankside.

Among the others to scoop an award was Logan Chatfield.

He was only 10 when he woke to find his grandad in severe pain.

The St John cadet, who had completed his emergency first aid training the week before, recognise the signs something was very wrong and took control of the situation, asking his nan to call 999 and loosening his granddad’s clothing.

He put him in the ‘W’ position, which is recommended in cases of suspected heart attack.

When the ambulance came, Logan was able to give them all the information about what had happened.

His grandad has recovered well after cardiac surgery, and you can watch the full story in the video above.

Young Hero winner Logan Chatfield, with his grandfather Paul Walsh (Picture: Johnny Green)

Volunteer Hero winners Alicia Lord (Left) and Lydia Hancock (Right) talked down a young suicidal male from a cliff edge (Picture: Johnny Green)

Community Hero winner Hastings Homeless Service (L-R) Roger Nuttall, Liz Rebalde, Dru Relf and Sandy Collver, with host Reverend Richard Coles (Picture: Johnny Green)

Highly Commended Volunteer Heroes Natalia Perdek (Left) and Tarhan Ibrahim (Picture: Johnny Green)

Other awards went to those who stepped in during harrowing emergencies, such as Natalia Perdek and Tarhan Ibrahim, who performed CPR for nearly half an hour on a woman who they found in cardiac arrest outside a tube station. She was taken to hospital after regaining a pulse, with police praising the pair for their courage and commitment to saving her life.

St John Ambulance’s Chief Executive, Martin Houghton-Brown congratulated all the award winners, saying: ‘Last night I had the honour of celebrating with the truly incredible ordinary people whose moments of extraordinary heroism allow us to put their humanity, care and courage in the spotlight.

‘Many of these are young people, who are the healthcare professionals and community leaders of the future, and their courage is just what our communities need and want. St John has been equipping people like this for 140 years and I am delighted that we can honour this long history with a celebration of our Everyday Heroes.’
